newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS - Difficult conditions hit Australian retailers.
newsitem.headline: RTRS - Difficult conditions hit Australian retailers.

text.p: First quarter sales results released on Monday by two large Australian retailers reflected continuing difficult trading conditions, analysts said.

Upmarket department store group David Jones Ltd reported first quarter sales of A$310.5 million, down 2.9 percent from a year earlier, while retail giant Coles Myer Ltd said sales for the 13 weeks to October 27 rose 5.6 percent to A$4.45 billion.
The rise at Coles was well above inflation but lower than growth in recent quarters, reflecting the general slowing in retail sales across the industry, the company said.
David Jones said its results reflected a continuation of the difficult retail environment in the fourth quarter last year.
"The low levels of consumer confidence and, in particular, concerns about job security have had a depressing impact on consumer spending," it said.
David Jones said it hoped for a further cut in official interest rates, which could boost spending in the lead up to Christmas.
Analysts, however, said a rate cut was likely to be only mildly positive.

"I think employment security is more important than interest rates at the moment," said Macquarie Equities retail analyst Simon Shakesheff. "People are worried about jobs and a half point change in interest rates is not going to change that."
A second analyst said the results showed trading conditions remained fairly tough.
"The food side is still pretty strong ... but the discretionary side is pretty difficult," the analyst said.
Coles Myer managing director Peter Bartels, who described the first quarter results as satisfactory, said the company had adopted a cautious approach to the critical Christmas period.
"But we are hopeful that customers will respond to the stable economic environment and adopt a more relaxed approach to spending over the next few months," he said in a statement.
Macquarie's Shakesheff said it could take some time for consumers to feel comfortable and increase their spending.
"Christmas at this stage is shaping up as fairly tough," he said.
"I think we are looking at this time next year for things to go better if the general economic scenario is correct," Shakesheff said.
